title: Managing Complex Projects – Network Methods and Crashing
headline: Upgrade your project management skills with advanced methods of running complex projects in this free online course.
description: How can you deliver on a project under cost and time constraints? What project management tools can help you manage your time with a tight deadline? This advanced course is designed to help project managers control complex projects. It covers the fundamentals of network diagrams and the Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT). You will also learn ways of calculating and reducing the duration of a project using different methods.

courseDescription:
The field of project management is one with significant scope and many applications containing varying degrees of complexity. The more complex a project, the more advanced the methods required to handle it. As a project manager, one must have sound knowledge and a clear understanding of the techniques, methods and evaluation of different durations of activities on a project. This in-depth professional course delves deeply into these advanced methodologies to take your skills to the next level.

We begin the course by exploring network analysis methods and their concepts. Learn how to build network diagrams and the roles of ‘slack’ and ‘float’ in the process. We explore the fundamentals of the Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) method and the calculations involved. Analyse the probability of completing a project within a timeframe and calculate the duration with different time constraints on the relevant events. Discover how to reduce the duration and the total cost of a project using the ‘crashing’ method.

Delivering results under constraints is a highly desired skill in project management. This course focuses on different methods for finding the critical path and how to ‘crash’ a project to reduce the overall project completion time with multiple critical approaches to the project. Step-by-step demonstrations of each method will give practical guidance throughout the process. With this advanced course in network methods and project crashing, take your project management skills to the next level. Continue your journey to success and enrol today.

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will explore the concept of a network diagram, as well as different methods, which include AON (Activity on Node) and AOA (Activity on Arrow). You will also learn how to calculate different timings of the activities in a project.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will master the techniques used to find the critical path of a project. You will go on to understand the fundamentals of PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and explore the concepts and applications of project crashing.
topics: Critical Path, PERT and Crashing – Learning Outcomes

topics: Managing Complex Projects – Network Methods and Crashing - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain the fundamentals of creating an Activity on Arrow (AOA) and Activity on node (AON) network diagram.
    • Compute the Earliest start and Earliest finish times of the activities on a project.
    • Define the Latest start and Earliest finish time for the activities on a project.
    • Solve for the slack of an event on a project.
    • Discuss the float of an activity on a project.
    • Identify the basics of interfering and free float of an activity on a project.
    • List the fundamentals of independent float of an activity on a project.

  • Network Methods - Lesson Summary

  • After the completion of this module, you will have the knowledge of: 
  • Network Diagrams make it easy to understand the precedence relationships of activities for complex and large projects.

    Components of Network diagram:
    • Activity – the smallest unit of work effort consuming both time and resources.
    • Event – the point at which one or more activities are to be completed and one or more other activities are to begin. It does not consume time and resources.

    Different approaches to Network Diagrams:
    • Activity on Arc (AOA) network – In this method, activities are represented as arrows and circles or nodes are used to represent events.
    • Activity on Node (AON) network – In this method, the nodes represents the activities and the arrows represents the sequence between these activities.

  • Network Methods - Lesson Summary

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Describe how to find a critical path on a project.
    • Analyze different methods of finding a critical path on a project at different activity times.
    • Discuss the fundamentals of PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique).
    • Describe the concepts of crashing using different aspects of critical path.

  • Critical Path - Lesson Summary

  • Critical Path: The set of sequential activities which takes the longest time between the first and the last node of a project is known as the Critical path of the project. Generally, the critical path also denotes the duration of the project.

    Methods to find out the critical path:

    1. If the total float of an activity is zero then it is on critical path.

    2. Following 3 conditions should all be met to find out the critical activity:
            · Earliest occurrence time (for the Tail event) = Latest occurrence time (for the Tail event)
            · Earliest occurrence time (for the Head event) = Latest occurrence time (for the Head event)
            · Ej - Ei = Lj - Li = ti j
    where, E = Earliest occurrence time
                 L = Latest occurrence time
                 i = Tail event of the activity
                 j = Head event of the activity
                 t = Duration of the activity

    3. To take all the combinations of activities from the starting node to the ending node finding the duration of these activities and whichever path has the maximum duration is the critical path.

  • Critical Path - Lesson Summary

  • Critical Path: The set of sequential activities which takes the longest time between the first and the last node of a project is known as the Critical path of the project. Generally, the critical path also denotes the duration of the project.

    Methods to find out the critical path:

    1. If the total float of an activity is zero then it is on critical path.

    2. Following 3 conditions should all be met to find out the critical activity:
            · Earliest occurrence time (for the Tail event) = Latest occurrence time (for the Tail event)
            · Earliest occurrence time (for the Head event) = Latest occurrence time (for the Head event)
            · Ej - Ei = Lj - Li = ti j
    where, E = Earliest occurrence time
                 L = Latest occurrence time
                 i = Tail event of the activity
                 j = Head event of the activity
                 t = Duration of the activity

    3. To take all the combinations of activities from the starting node to the ending node finding the duration of these activities and whichever path has the maximum duration is the critical path.
